author: Grimms
text: There was once a man called Frederick: he had a wife whose name was Catherine, and they had not long been married.

author: Grimms
text: One day Frederick said.

author: Grimms
text: "Kate!

author: Grimms
text: I am going to work in the fields; when I come back I shall be hungry so let me have something nice cooked, and a good draught of ale."

author: Grimms
text: "Very well," said she, "it shall all be ready."

author: Grimms
text: When dinner-time drew nigh, Catherine took a nice steak, which was all the meat she had, and put it on the fire to fry.

author: Grimms
text: The steak soon began to look brown, and to crackle in the pan; and Catherine stood by with a fork and turned it: then she said to herself, "The steak is almost ready, I may as well go to the cellar for the ale."

author: Grimms
text: So she left the pan on the fire and took a large jug and went into the cellar and tapped the ale cask.

author: Grimms
text: The beer ran into the jug and Catherine stood looking on.

author: Grimms
text: At last it popped into her head, "The dog is not shut up--he may be running away with the steak; that"s well thought of."

author: Grimms
text: So up she ran from the cellar; and sure enough the rascally cur had got the steak in his mouth, and was making off with it.

author: Grimms
text: Away ran Catherine, and away ran the dog across the field: but he ran faster than she, and stuck close to the steak.

author: Grimms
text: "It"s all gone, and "what can"t be cured must be endured"," said Catherine.

author: Grimms
text: So she turned round; and as she had run a good way and was tired, she walked home leisurely to cool herself.

author: Grimms
text: Now all this time the ale was running too, for Catherine had not turned the cock; and when the jug was full the liquor ran upon the floor till the cask was empty.

author: Grimms
text: When she got to the cellar stairs she saw what had happened.

author: Grimms
text: "My stars!" said she, "what shall I do to keep Frederick from seeing all this slopping about?"

author: Grimms
text: So she thought a while; and at last remembered that there was a sack of fine meal bought at the last fair, and that if she sprinkled this over the floor it would suck up the ale nicely.

author: Grimms
text: "What a lucky thing," said she, "that we kept that meal! we have now a good use for it."

author: Grimms
text: So away she went for it: but she managed to set it down just upon the great jug full of beer, and upset it; and thus all the ale that had been saved was set swimming on the floor also.

author: Grimms
text: "Ah! well," said she, "when one goes another may as well follow."

author: Grimms
text: Then she strewed the meal all about the cellar, and was quite pleased with her cleverness, and said, "How very neat and clean it looks!"

author: Grimms
text: At noon Frederick came home.

author: Grimms
text: "Now, wife," cried he, "what have you for dinner?"

author: Grimms
text: "O Frederick!" answered she, "I was cooking you a steak; but while I went down to draw the ale, the dog ran away with it; and while I ran after him, the ale ran out; and when I went to dry up the ale with the sack of meal that we got at the fair, I upset the jug: but the cellar is now quite dry, and looks so clean!"

author: Grimms
text: "Kate, Kate," said he, "how could you do all this?"

author: Grimms
text: Why did you leave the steak to fry, and the ale to run, and then spoil all the meal?"

author: Grimms
text: "Why, Frederick," said she, "I did not know I was doing wrong; you should have told me before."

author: Grimms
text: The husband thought to himself, "If my wife manages matters thus, I must look sharp myself."

author: Grimms
text: Now he had a good deal of gold in the house: so he said to Catherine, "What pretty yellow buttons these are!

author: Grimms
text: I shall put them into a box and bury them in the garden; but take care that you never go near or meddle with them."

author: Grimms
text: "No, Frederick," said she, "that I never will."

author: Grimms
text: As soon as he was gone, there came by some pedlars with earthenware plates and dishes, and they asked her whether she would buy.

author: Grimms
text: "Oh dear me, I should like to buy very much, but I have no money: if you had any use for yellow buttons, I might deal with you."

author: Grimms
text: "Yellow buttons!" said they: "let us have a look at them."

author: Grimms
text: "Go into the garden and dig where I tell you, and you will find the yellow buttons: I dare not go myself."

author: Grimms
text: So the rogues went: and when they found what these yellow buttons were, they took them all away, and left her plenty of plates and dishes.

author: Grimms
text: Then she set them all about the house for a show: and when Frederick came back, he cried out, "Kate, what have you been doing?"

author: Grimms
text: "See," said she, "I have bought all these with your yellow buttons: but I did not touch them myself; the pedlars went themselves and dug them up."

author: Grimms
text: "Wife, wife," said Frederick, "what a pretty piece of work you have made! those yellow buttons were all my money: how came you to do such a thing?"

author: Grimms
text: "Why," answered she, "I did not know there was any harm in it; you should have told me."

author: Grimms
text: Catherine stood musing for a while, and at last said to her husband, "Hark ye, Frederick, we will soon get the gold back: let us run after the thieves."

author: Grimms
text: "Well, we will try," answered he; "but take some butter and cheese with you, that we may have something to eat by the way."

author: Grimms
text: "Very well," said she; and they set out: and as Frederick walked the fastest, he left his wife some way behind.

author: Grimms
text: "It does not matter," thought she: "when we turn back, I shall be so much nearer home than he."

author: Grimms
text: Presently she came to the top of a hill, down the side of which there was a road so narrow that the cart wheels always chafed the trees on each side as they passed.

author: Grimms
text: "Ah, see now," said she, "how they have bruised and wounded those poor trees; they will never get well."

author: Grimms
text: So she took pity on them, and made use of the butter to grease them all, so that the wheels might not hurt them so much.

author: Grimms
text: While she was doing this kind office one of her cheeses fell out of the basket, and rolled down the hill.

author: Grimms
text: Catherine looked, but could not see where it had gone; so she said, "Well, I suppose the other will go the same way and find you; he has younger legs than I have."

author: Grimms
text: Then she rolled the other cheese after it; and away it went, nobody knows where, down the hill.

author: Grimms
text: But she said she supposed that they knew the road, and would follow her, and she could not stay there all day waiting for them.

author: Grimms
text: At last she overtook Frederick, who desired her to give him something to eat.

author: Grimms
text: Then she gave him the dry bread.

author: Grimms
text: "Where are the butter and cheese?" said he.

author: Grimms
text: "Oh!" answered she, "I used the butter to grease those poor trees that the wheels chafed so: and one of the cheeses ran away so I sent the other after it to find it, and I suppose they are both on the road together somewhere."

author: Grimms
text: "What a goose you are to do such silly things!" said the husband.

author: Grimms
text: "How can you say so?" said she; "I am sure you never told me not."

author: Grimms
text: They ate the dry bread together; and Frederick said, "Kate, I hope you locked the door safe when you came away."

author: Grimms
text: "No," answered she, "you did not tell me."

author: Grimms
text: "Then go home, and do it now before we go any farther," said Frederick, "and bring with you something to eat."

author: Grimms
text: Catherine did as he told her, and thought to herself by the way, "Frederick wants something to eat; but I don"t think he is very fond of butter and cheese: I"ll bring him a bag of fine nuts, and the vinegar, for I have often seen him take some."

author: Grimms
text: When she reached home, she bolted the back door, but the front door she took off the hinges, and said, "Frederick told me to lock the door, but surely it can nowhere be so safe if I take it with me."

author: Grimms
text: So she took her time by the way; and when she overtook her husband she cried out, "There, Frederick, there is the door itself, you may watch it as carefully as you please."

author: Grimms
text: "Alas! alas!" said he, "what a clever wife I have!

author: Grimms
text: I sent you to make the house fast, and you take the door away, so that everybody may go in and out as they please--however, as you have brought the door, you shall carry it about with you for your pains."

author: Grimms
text: "Very well," answered she, "I"ll carry the door; but I"ll not carry the nuts and vinegar bottle also--that would be too much of a load; so if you please, I"ll fasten them to the door."

author: Grimms
text: Frederick of course made no objection to that plan, and they set off into the wood to look for the thieves; but they could not find them: and when it grew dark, they climbed up into a tree to spend the night there.

author: Grimms
text: Scarcely were they up, than who should come by but the very rogues they were looking for.

author: Grimms
text: They were in truth great rascals, and belonged to that class of people who find things before they are lost; they were tired; so they sat down and made a fire under the very tree where Frederick and Catherine were.

author: Grimms
text: Frederick slipped down on the other side, and picked up some stones.

author: Grimms
text: Then he climbed up again, and tried to hit the thieves on the head with them: but they only said, "It must be near morning, for the wind shakes the fir-apples down."

author: Grimms
text: Catherine, who had the door on her shoulder, began to be very tired; but she thought it was the nuts upon it that were so heavy: so she said softly, "Frederick, I must let the nuts go."

author: Grimms
text: "No," answered he, "not now, they will discover us."

author: Grimms
text: "I can"t help that: they must go."

author: Grimms
text: "Well, then, make haste and throw them down, if you will."

author: Grimms
text: Then away rattled the nuts down among the boughs and one of the thieves cried, "Bless me, it is hailing."

author: Grimms
text: A little while after, Catherine thought the door was still very heavy: so she whispered to Frederick, "I must throw the vinegar down."

author: Grimms
text: "Pray don"t," answered he, "it will discover us."

author: Grimms
text: "I can"t help that," said she, "go it must."

author: Grimms
text: So she poured all the vinegar down; and the thieves said, "What a heavy dew there is!"

author: Grimms
text: At last it popped into Catherine"s head that it was the door itself that was so heavy all the time: so she whispered, "Frederick, I must throw the door down soon."

author: Grimms
text: But he begged and prayed her not to do so, for he was sure it would betray them.

author: Grimms
text: "Here goes, however," said she: and down went the door with such a clatter upon the thieves, that they cried out "Murder!" and not knowing what was coming, ran away as fast as they could, and left all the gold.

author: Grimms
text: So when Frederick and Catherine came down, there they found all their money safe and sound.
